Posts.Content: Hi Oksana, I too had WLE back in November and quickly developed swelling under armpit which was a Seroma. Has that been mentioned to you? I had to have it drained and then developed another which I had drained again but developed another which I decided to leave alone and which went away on its own eventually. As someone else described it - it's like having a rolled up newspaper under your arm so you can't quite put your arm down. It was explained to me that because the lymph drainage on the operation side had been removed, your body has to readjust and find other lymph channel to drain though. Thankfully mine seems to have done that now and hopefully yours will too although you could ask about having it drained.  Good luck with it X
Posts.Title: Axillary clearance post surgery swelling or lymphodema?

Posts.Content: Hi there, I'm a little bit behind you in terms of treatment and haven't yet started chemo but have also decided to use the cold cap (after watching BBC journalist Victoria Derbyshire's cancer diaries - probs on you tube). She kept about half her hair but still wore a wig in public. Like you I'm thinking about getting a shorter cut so can't offer any advice but please keep posting so I can learn from your experience.  And no, you're not a vain cow - just a woman who wants to retain some femininity throughout this bloody awful ordeal. I know I do.  Good luck.  X
Posts.Title: Taking the haircut plunge!

Posts.Content: Hi Fluff, so have you continued to work through chemo? Onviously I don't know yet if I will have chemo but will definitely have radiotherapy and was advised that I shouldn't be working (I'm a teacher). But if I feel as good as I do today throughout treatment,   I will feel so guilty not being in school.
Posts.Title: Immediate post - op experience lumpectomy and Axillary node clearance...

Posts.Content: Thank you Lynne and Annie. I will heed your advice. Tracy x
Posts.Title: Immediate post - op experience lumpectomy and Axillary node clearance...

Posts.Content: Hello everyone, I have recently joined the cancer club (mammogram 3 weeks ago and surgery yesterday). I had lumpectomy and Axillary node clearance yesterday after being diagnosed with invasive ductal (cancer in 1 lymph node found during biopsy) and am now waiting to find out if I will need chemo before radiotherapy. I hap op about 2pm yesterday and was allowed home after drain was removed about 8pm. My query is - I feel remarkably well, pain-free and able to use the affected arm quite well. I'm wondering if this is the calm before the storm. I actually feel a fraud being off work. Most of the reading I have done has been about pain, swelling, numbness etc following this surgery. Am I just lucky or it's not happened YET? Anyone else had this experience?
Posts.Title: Immediate post - op experience lumpectomy and Axillary node clearance...

Posts.Content: Thanks, Jo. It's going to be very hard for me to 'take it easy'. I'm always on the go. Hubby is telling me off because I'm already talking about going back to work!  Tracy
Posts.Title: Immediate post - op experience lumpectomy and Axillary node clearance...

Posts.Content: Thanks again, Jo and K. I'm planning on having the 2 weeks off as advised while I wait for the pathology and see what's next. I've no drain in and so far so good. I'll try my best to take it easy. Thanks for your replies. Hope things are going well for you both. Tracy x
Posts.Title: Immediate post - op experience lumpectomy and Axillary node clearance...

Posts.Content: Yeah. I thought that might be the case. I'm taking the anti-inflammatory they prescribed just in case but as yet no need for painkillers. Fingers crossed I am one of those lucky one because it seems a lot of people do have problems.  Thanks for your reply.
Posts.Title: Immediate post - op experience lumpectomy and Axillary node clearance...

Posts.Content: It's good to hear positive experiences post op since everything I'd read on Internet suggested it was all bad news. Thanks for your reply Tracy
Posts.Title: Immediate post - op experience lumpectomy and Axillary node clearance...

Posts.Content: Thanks to everyone for useful advice. I haven't quite got my head around it all yet. Just feels like a regular Sunday rather than being off sick. Like the sound of watching TV and a duvet day though.  Tracy
Posts.Title: Immediate post - op experience lumpectomy and Axillary node clearance...

Posts.Content: I like it
Posts.Title: Immediate post - op experience lumpectomy and Axillary node clearance...

Posts.Content: Fingers crossed I avoid chemo and just have the radiotherapy, but thanks for your advice. Tracy
Posts.Title: Immediate post - op experience lumpectomy and Axillary node clearance...

Posts.Content: It's a week and 1 day since I had my op and I have been back today for checkup with breast nurse and breast physio. I had noticed some swelling developing under arm in last 48 hours which was beginning to make me feel like I was walking around carrying a rolled up carpet. Turns out it was a seroma which has been drained and I now feel much more comfortable. The nurses gave me a good talking to about how much I've been doing (cleaning windows, vacuuming, etc - although I have been trying to use my unaffected arm) and have made me realise that an axillary node clearance (rather than the lumpectomy) is a big operation. Having thought that I might soon start radiotherapy (provided I don't need chemo) they told me it won't be for at least another 6 weeks until the ANC is fully healed and that I shouldn't be driving for another 6 weeks and probably won't be fit to go back to work until Easter. They were very firm that I must rest and only do light occasional housework (even with my other hand). I just can't get my head around all this because, otherwise, I feel so well and still feel guilty for being off work. It's going to be hard, but I am going to try to follow their instructions because I do not want to develop lymphodaema (I've seen google images)!
Posts.Title: Immediate post - op experience lumpectomy and Axillary node clearance...

Posts.Content: Thanks again. Xx
Posts.Title: Immediate post - op experience lumpectomy and Axillary node clearance...

Posts.Content: Thank you all. I’m really not worrying unduly - just wondering if I was missing out on screening others were getting but it appears not. Thanks again
Posts.Title: Screening once treatment is all finished

Posts.Content: Hi everyone I know there are lots of ‘veterans’ on here who’ve been through BC like me and come out the other side, so this is a question for you if you can help please.   I watched an interview with a radio 5 presenter talking about her secondary cancer etc this week and then I ‘googled’ her story. I found that she had found her BC in November 2016 just like me and pretty much gone through same treatment as me but has subsequently developed secondaries.I don’t know how these were discovered but it sparked a conversation with my brother (who had bowel cancer a few years back) about follow ups when treatment has finished. I just have to wait from year to year for a mammogram but he said in his first few years after treatment he had six-monthly blood tests to check foe cancer markers in his blood. Now, I’m not a pessimist or a worrier but I do wonder - if I’m just reliant on annual mammograms, how would I know it’s not returned elsewhere until I: find a lump, feel unwell, etc, in which case it might be too advanced? My own mum developed secondary oesophagal cancer after her treatment which was too late to treat.  Is anyone else getting any sort of screening apart from mammograms? Should I be asking for regular blood tests? Thank you.
Posts.Title: Screening once treatment is all finished

Posts.Content: Interesting how different things are around the country. I wasn’t offered check-ups with breast care nurse although I know she is at the end of the phone if I have any worries.  Good luck with the BMI reduction.  As for the annual mammogram -mine was pretty much a year from the one that detected it.
Posts.Title: Screening once treatment is all finished

Posts.Content: Hello lovely people. I’ve been taking letrozole for the past 2 years following surgery, chemo and radiotherapy with usual niggles (joints, hot flushes, complete loss of libido,etc) and am feeling really down. I think this is more to do with life issues (unhappy marriage and kids leaving home although maybe letrozole a factor??.) I have been considering seeing doctor about anti-depressants or taking St John’s Wort but have been reading online lots of conflicting articles about taking either. I’d be grateful for replies from anyone in a similar situation and for your experiences or what you’ve been told.  Thank you.
Posts.Title: Taking anti-depressants or St John’s Wort with letrozole

Posts.Content: Thanks to all of you for replying. I have been trying to see a gp (impossible unless it’s an emergency at my doctor’s!)  but will try again and look into the sertraline.  Thanks again. It’s always good to get advice from those who’ve ‘been there’ (although I wish none of us has).
Posts.Title: Taking anti-depressants or St John’s Wort with letrozole

Posts.Content: Thanks Leolady. I think I will ask the radio therapist.
Posts.Title: Skin changes months after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Worried, I did try sending you a private message but it wouldn't recognise your name???  I just wondered how you got on with this issue because the exact same thing has just happened to me almost 9 months after radiotherapy (which I sailed through without so much as a blister thankfully). Same as you, it's the underside whilst my tumour was above and I also have the orange peel thing going on and the ridges. Should I be worried or is this also a 'normal'? I also had annual mammogram last October and all okay.
Posts.Title: Skin changes months after radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Jmco4  Just want to add my best wishes. I'm also awaiting scan results and can empathise with you as can so many others on here. Your mind does go into overdrive doesn't it? Try and stay positive - I do believe it's half the battle although I 'have my moments' and fear the worst too.  Stay strong and keep posting xx
Posts.Title: I need help please.

Posts.Content: Hi Optimistic (love your name). I was in your shoes just last week. I had full WLE because 1 lymph node was found cancerous during biopsy and had a two week wait for results. In my head I sat in the consulting room being told I had secondary cancer everywhere and I convinced myself that a mild cough I had was secondary lung cancer. The reality was that I had 4 out of 11 nodes affected but that the scan was clear. I cannot predict your outcome of course and I know you won't stop worrying until you get your results so I just wanted to send you a virtual hug.  Tracy xx
Posts.Title: Worrying again

Posts.Content: Thank you, Leolady, I will go and see my GP next week. If antidepressants can help, I will take them. I read the link you posted - all very true. I guess I am at some sort of crossroads in my life but there's only me who can decide which way I go. Giving up a very stressful job is just the first step. Thanks again.
Posts.Title: Does anyone else feel totally emotionless taking Letrozole?

Posts.Content: I have been taking Letrozole for the past 2 years and apart from mild stiffness in my feet first thing in the morning and the usual night sweats, feel okay on it. I am however, completely devoid of any sexual desires whatsoever even to the point of not wanting a cuddle and it's making me feel miserable: I want to feel like a woman (I'm 54).  I wonder if I'm depressed and that that is the cause of my feelings or whether the Letrozole is causing it.  I've just resigned my job as a teacher because I'm totally stressed out and now feel even more depressed about what to do instead.  On top of all that I know I am suffering from empty nest syndrome as my eldest daughter left home last year and my younger daughter flits in and out, mostly staying with her boyfriend.  I feel totally worthless and useless and am going to see the doctor to see if I should be taking antidepressants (don't really want to though). I've even had some counselling (not sure what that was supposed to do though since the counsellor just listened and didn't offer any advice).  I just wondered if anyone anyone else has felt like this?
Posts.Title: Does anyone else feel totally emotionless taking Letrozole?

Posts.Content: Thanks to all of you for replying. Maybe a change of job (I’ve quit teaching but still need to work) will help! We’ll see.   X
Posts.Title: Does anyone else feel totally emotionless taking Letrozole?
